captions.text:
The little scar in the middle of your abdomen
marks the place where, for about nine glorious

months, all the nutrients you needed to grow
and develop and survive flowed straight into

your bloodstream while you just floated around
in a sac of amniotic fluid. But have you ever

wondered what was going on with your other
bodily functions while you were in that enclosed

space? To put it a little more bluntly, did
you, you know, pee and poop in there?

The answer to question #1 is yes, definitely:
embryos start peeing after just two months

of development, around the time they first
begin swallowing--and, therefore, drinking--amniotic
fluid.

This does essentially mean that fetuses spend
seven months drinking their own pee, but that's

actually not as gross as it sounds. For one
thing, urine--unlike feces--is sterile, so

it doesn't contain bacteria that could make
the fetus sick. Also, the waste products we

normally get rid of by urinating, like excess
nitrogen, are instead filtered from the fetus

and delivered, through the umbilical cord,
back to the mother for disposal.

And what about the waste we normally get rid
of by pooping? Well, mom takes care of that,

too - indirectly. She digests food before
it gets to the baby, absorbing nutrients like

sugar and protein into her bloodstream and
then passing those nutrients to her fetus

through the umbilical cord. So most of the
potential poop products stay with the mother.

The fetus's digestive system isn't totally
empty, though: some waste does go there and

get broken down by acidic bile in the small
intestines, producing a slimy, sticky greenish

mass called meconium. But, unlike the large
intestine of everyone outside a womb, a fetus's

large intestine is mostly sterile and devoid
of the billions of bacteria that break down

our waste and make up as much as 50% of the
brown pulp known as feces.

So the green, sticky mass that forms in a
fetus's small intestines eventually becomes

a green, sticky, and mostly bacteria-free
mass inside the baby's first dirty diaper.

And in a way, it's the first--and last--clean
poop in anyone's life.

comments.text:
Note: Pee is *not* sterile. Not for any purpose you conclusion-jumping 
monkeys in the comment section might want.

*Pee is only sterile before reaching the urethra*, which means that unless 
you are extracting pee directly from your kidneys, the pee you are using is 
*not* sterile.

Meconium is *also not sterile*. Don't twist the video's words to your 
depraved wanted meanings. Meconium is, as the video implies, *mostly* 
sterile; Not *completely* or *always* sterile. Bacteria colonies of 
*Lactobacillus* and *Escherichia coli* have been found in "first-poop" 
Meconium.

For people too lazy to research, *Lactobacillus* is related to digesting 
milk. And *Escherichia coli*, AKA *"E. coli"* can be normal in the human 
digestive system, *but hold your horses*, because each person has their own 
internal bacterial biome, and ingesting *"E. coli"* that is strange to your 
body *can, and probably will*, lead to *gastroenteritis* and *urinary tract 
infection*.﻿

comments.author: What's Their Name Again?

comments.text:
+umidontno040394 no. e.g (con)censuses, nex(us)es, genera/genuses (from 
genus)
(us -> i) plurals come from latin's second declension masculine nouns. (us 
-> es) as in nexes, comes from latin's fifth declension. "Genera" is an 
example from latin's third declension plural (for a neuter noun).
comments.author: klieu90210

comments.text:

that is interesting with the different word origins but, THIS IS ENGLISH!

comments.author: umidontno040394

comments.text:
+umidontno040394 I can understand that and I actually agree with you.

But apparently, the reason why it is 'incorrect' to say 'platypi' and 
'octopi' is that those are Greek words and the Greek plural formation from 
'pus' (foot) is 'podes'. (Note that 'platypodes' is not a used plural for 
'platypus', though.)
'Foetus' or 'cactus' are Latin words that is why the plural formation from 
'us' to 'i' is considered correct.

I personally prefer 'cacti' and 'foeti' to 'cactuses' and 'foetuses', but 
I'll have to admit that I'd rather say 'octopodes' and 'platypodes'.

EDIT: spelling.
comments.author: What's Their Name Again?

comments.text:

flows better.
language always has room for evolution.
i am going to say "i"
comments.author: umidontno040394

comments.text:
According to Oxford Dictionary the plural is "fetuses" or "foetuses" 
whereas Merriam-Webster states it is "fetuses" or (chiefly British) either 
"foetuses" or "foeti".
comments.author: What's Their Name Again?

comments.text:
+umidontno040394 I thought the plural of the word 'octopus' is 'octopode'.
EDIT: I looked it up and found contradictory statements:

Oxford dictionary says: The most common plural is 'octopuses' while 
'octopodes' is still occasionally used. 'Octopi' is *incorrect*

Merriam Webster says: The plural is either 'octopuses' or 'octopi' and 
there is no mention of 'octopodes'.

Conclusion: Use 'octopuses'.
